title: Part A
stimulusHtml:
A. Region Identification

(1 point total)

Africa, sub-Saharan Africa, Africa south of the Sahara, West Africa, Southern Africa, Central Africa, East Africa, or the Sahel, Sahelian

Do not accept: North Africa, South Africa
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

A. Region Identification

(1 point total)

Africa, sub-Saharan Africa, Africa south of the Sahara, West Africa, Southern Africa, Central Africa, East Africa, or the Sahel, Sahelian

Do not accept: North Africa, South Africa

The student response earns one of the following points:

A. Region Identification

(1 point total)

Africa, sub-Saharan Africa, Africa south of the Sahara, West Africa, Southern Africa, Central Africa, East Africa, or the Sahel, Sahelian

Do not accept: North Africa, South Africa

title: Part B
stimulusHtml:
B. Explain three factors that contribute to high population growth rates

(1 point for each factor, 3 points total (1+1+1). Each category may be used only once.)
descriptions:
The student response earns none of the following points:

B. Explain three factors that contribute to high population growth rates

(1 point for each factor, 3 points total (1+1+1). Each category may be used only once.)

The student response earns one of the following points:

B. Explain three factors that contribute to high population growth rates

(1 point for each factor, 3 points total (1+1+1). Each category may be used only once.)

The student response earns two of the following points:

B. Explain three factors that contribute to high population growth rates

(1 point for each factor, 3 points total (1+1+1). Each category may be used only once.)

The student response earns three of the following points:

B. Explain three factors that contribute to high population growth rates

(1 point for each factor, 3 points total (1+1+1). Each category may be used only once.)

title: Part C
stimulusHtml:
C. One economic incentive to decrease population growth

(1 description + 1 impact = 2 points total)

Economic Incentives (1 pt.)

  1. Increasing distribution, availability, or affordability of contraceptives to men and women

  2. Promoting economic development, poverty reduction, sustainable development

  3. Promoting female labor force participation or business ownership (e.g., microcredit, access to capital)

  4. Offering incentives for smaller families or disincentives for having larger families

  5. Implementing a government economic safety net to support the elderly

Potential Impacts (1 pt.)

  1. Reduced birth rates or fertility rates (lower population is not acceptable)

  2. Move from stage two to stage three of the demographic transition

  3. Fewer children lead to more resources for better education or health care

  4. Improved gender equality or female empowerment

  5. Conflicts between traditional social norms and new population programs

  6. Increased social tension between men and women

  7. Skewed gender ratio

  8. Increased elderly dependency ratio; population aging; reduced youth dependency ratio

title: Part D
stimulusHtml:
D. One social program to decrease population growth

(1 description + 1 impact = 2 points total)

Social Program or Policy (1 pt.)

  1. Promoting family planning, or reproductive health education

  2. Increasing education of girls, promoting higher education for women

  3. Implementing antinatalist policies that limit the number of children

  4. Improving healthcare for women, infants, and children

  5. Producing media or ad campaigns showing benefits of family planning practices

  6. Promoting urbanization

  7. Changing, implementing, or enforcing laws about increasing the minimum age at marriage

Potential Impacts (1 pt.)

  1. Reduced birth rates or fertility rates (lower population is not acceptable)

  2. Move from stage two to stage three of the demographic transition

  3. Fewer children lead to more resources for better education or health care

  4. Improved gender equality or female empowerment

  5. Conflicts between traditional social norms and new population programs

  6. Increased social tension between men and women

  7. Skewed gender ratio

  8. Increased elderly dependency ratio; population aging; reduced youth dependency ratio
